data.title: Adding and subtracting ASCII values:
data.solution:
import sys
import math

# Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
# the standard input according to the problem statement.

sentence = input()
n = int(input())
e = []
for i in range(n):
    e.append(int(input()))
res = 0
for i in sentence:
    if not (i.isupper() or i.islower()):
        res -= ord(i)
    else:
        res += ord(i)
temp = res
for i in e:
    if str(i) in str(temp):
        res += i
# Write an answer using print
# To debug: print("Debug messages...", file=sys.stderr, flush=True)

print(res)
data.statement: Given a sentence, for every letter in the sentence add the ASCII value to the result. For all other characters(spaces count as well) in the sentence subtract it from the result. Lastly for each of the given numbers except the second line, add it to the result if that number is in the string version of result (for example 5 is in 258 so 263).

data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>> An string [[sentence]] for the characters to turn into ASCII values.
<<Line 2>> An integer [[N]] for the amount of numbers given.
<<Next [[N]] lines>> An integer [[E]] for one of the numbers given.
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1>> The final result after adding the ASCII values of letters, subtracting the ASCII values of other characters, and adding specified numbers if they appear in the string version of the result.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Given a sentence, for every letter in the sentence add the ASCII value to the result. For all other characters(spaces count as well) in the sentence subtract it from the result. Lastly for each of the given numbers except the second line, add it to the result if that number is in the string version of result (for example 5 is in 258 so 263).
Input
Line 1 An string sentence for the characters to turn into ASCII values.
Line 2 An integer N for the amount of numbers given.
Next N lines An integer E for one of the numbers given.
Output
Line 1 The final result after adding the ASCII values of letters, subtracting the ASCII values of other characters, and adding specified numbers if they appear in the string version of the result.
Constraints
1 <= E <= 99
Example
Input
qwerty
3
5
55
1
Output
684
